It's become a tradition in recent years for the Rensselaer Park Elementary staff to draw inspiring messages and images on the sidewalk outside the school as a way to welcome back the students when they arrive on the first day.

For a moment the staff wasn't sure if they could carry on the tradition this year due to the recent cuts in New York State aid to school districts like Lansingburgh. The cuts meant that our Rensselaer Park students couldn't safely return to school in person for the time being, so was there a point to decorating the sidewalks this year? YES!

Earlier this week we arranged for Rensselaer Park students and families to stop by the school and pick-up district-provided school supplies for their remote learning school work. Before they started arriving, the RPES staff did their traditional welcome back sidewalk art for them to see when they came for their school supplies.

So glad we have a creative staff who still managed to spread some positivity to our students when they stopped by the school for their supplies!

We know many members of the Lansingburgh community had strong emotions after hearing Dr. Abitabile's announcement that the district was modifying its reopening plans. We came to that extremely difficult decision after being faced with a 20% cut in crucial New York State aid, a financial blow that made it virtually impossible for us to safely reopen the schools for all of our students in person.

We've had a number of community members ask what they can do to help. Step 1 is ensuring our elected officials are fully aware of what a 20% cut in state aid means for Lansingburgh. You can do this by reaching out to them and sharing how this will affect you, your family and your community.

If you'd like you can use the sample letter on our website to contact your elected officials. For your convenience, we've also provided a list of a number of elected officials and their contact information. Every voice counts during these times.

Dear Lansingburgh School Community,

During his daily briefing today, Governor Cuomo gave an update on reopening schools in September. To date, district employees have had various discussions to begin planning for different scenarios (in-person, remote and hybrid), ranging from the social/emotional needs of our staff and students to the additional resources needed, such as personal protective equipment, cleaning supplies, etc. Today, Governor Cuomo indicated that this guidance will be released on July 13. Individual school district reopening plans will be due to the state by July 31 and the Governor will make a decision on reopening during the week of August 1.

As you can imagine, we have a lot of work to finalize a reopening plan that ensures the safety of our students and staff. We ask for your patience as we work through this process.

Sincerely,

Dr. Antonio W. Abitabile
LCSD Superintendent of Schools

Dr. Abitabile explains what happens if Lansingburgh needs to adopt a contingency budget, one of the options if voters do not approve the proposed budget next Tuesday. Adopting a contingency budget means:
-No community use of school facilities (gym, fields etc.)
-Not buying our student’s school supplies as we've done the last 2 years
-Not buying important equipment unless there’s an emergency
-An impact on district-provided transportation for Knights Athletic Programs

In the coming days, we're sharing some Flashback Stories from the recent past in our district. When the current national situation quickly escalated we had to hold off sharing some planned stories with you. We can all use some positivity, though, so we didn't want to waste them!

On March 12, writer/artist John Bemelmans Marciano graciously visited Rensselaer Park Elementary students. Mr. Marciano is the author of a variety of books for students ages 8-11, so he was the perfect person to visit our Rensselaer Park readers! Mr. Marciano answered a bunch of the students' questions about writing and even read a few chapters from one of his "Klawde: Evil Alien Warlord Cat" graphic novels!

Ms. Schweda's 4th-grade class joined in efforts to help Australia's animals displaced from the country's devastating fires, specifically the marsupials (koalas and kangaroos) living in rescue centers. The mother of a student in Mr. Schweda's class helped them sew pouches for these mammals who no longer have their mother's pouches to live in.

Ms. Schweda's class also created thank you cards for the rescue workers and they "adopted" a young koala living in one of the rescue sanctuaries. The homemade pouches and cards will now be sent off to Australia.

January 27 at 1:01 PM · Troy, NY ·

Mr. Gregoire's Rensselaer Park Elementary science classes are working on an "Eco-column" observation project for the next few weeks.

They built their eco-columns using 2-liter soda bottles, filling them with a plant, decomposing materials and an aquatic chamber with a fish.

The project goal is building a self-sustaining environment that lasts 3 weeks without any human interference, meaning the fish are naturally fed with the nutrients in their eco-columns.

Once each week, small groups of students observe their eco-columns and log what they see to form conclusions about why certain things are happening.

A plethora of STEM lessons happening at Lansingburgh in recent weeks!

The first four pictures are Mrs. Dyer's Computer Programming classes working with IT faculty (Mrs. Fusco & Mrs. Gibson) to practice writing block code to get Sphero mini-robots moving around. Crucially they were supposed to have them move around in the way they intended, which they learned is harder than it looks!

The rest of the pictures are Ms. Thorpe's first graders working on a holiday STEM challenge, engineering a shelf for an elf. It needed to be a safe and high place for the elf to sit, so they followed the engineering design process: Ask, Imagine, Plan, Test and Improve, then Reflect & Present.

A brisk but fun and educational experience! The 7th-grade Green Team explored the wetland ecosystem of Grafton Lakes State Park and determined if the water source was dirty or clean based on the water life. Using nets, they caught multiple biological specimens including tadpoles, newts, crayfish and various small creatures.

Students also hiked along Long Pond, learning about ecological succession and land formation. Team building was a theme of the day, with students working together solving various puzzles. The day was topped off with a little time on the Park's new playground.

The student's name then goes on a star on the bulletin board outside of the Main Office and their name is announced on the RPES Morning Show, along with a letter of recognition sent home.
